Building and Evaluating Ethical Robotic Systems
IROS-2021 • October 1, 2021 • 16:00 - 18:00 CEST

About

The deployment of robotic systems has been accelerating across an array of domains that pose a serious impact on society. For example, robotic systems have recently been involved in applications that range from elder care support and autonomous driving to nuclear energy production and military technology. However, while our ability to build robotic systems that integrate into our daily lives has expanded over the years, it has inevitably outstripped our ability to build robotic systems that can account for the large number of different ethical considerations that may arise during operation. This workshop therefore focuses on building and evaluating ethical robotic systems at every level of the robotics stack while broadening the scope of areas that should be considered by researchers, such as how users can interact with new and existing technology or how legislators can develop actionable standards and regulations.

This workshop aims to bring together researchers from academia and industry to discuss key challenges, learn from real-world case studies, identify potential research avenues, explore recent technical advances, present novel data sets, and survey existing work related to ethical robotic systems. Given this aim, we invite contributions that draw from a range of methods in artificial intelligence and robotics, such as planning, reinforcement learning, machine learning, deep learning, human-robot interaction, safety, explainability, transparency, formal verification, social preferences, and human factors. Most importantly, we welcome researchers from an array of disciplines, including philosophy, psychology, sociology, and law, in order to represent diverse perspectives on building and evaluating ethical robotic systems.

Relevant research topics include but are not limited to:

  • Value alignment in robotic systems
  • Cultural, political, and societal impacts of robotics
  • Methods for analyzing the ethical implications of autonomous systems
  • Moral reasoning in autonomous systems
  • Ethical compliance in robotic systems
  • Ethically sensitive design and implementation of autonomous systems
  • Law, regulation, and governance of robotics
  • Challenges of building and evaluating ethical robotic systems
  • Ethical models and algorithms in robotic systems
  • Impacts of robotics on vulnerable groups

Contact: ers-workshop@gmail.com

Submissions

We encourage a range of submission types to faciliate broad participation:

  • Full Technical Paper (up to 6 pages)
  • Short Technical Paper (up to 4 pages)
  • Highlight Paper (up to 2 pages)
  • Survey Paper (up to 8 pages)
  • Case Study Paper (up to 6 pages)
  • Position Paper (up to 4 pages)

Note that there is no page limit for references and supplementary materials. Submissions should be in PDF and follow the IROS 2021 format guidelines. Papers published, accepted, or under review at other conferences can be submitted and presented at the workshop subject to the conference guidelines. All accepted papers will be included in an electronic, non-archival proceedings.

Dates

The tentative dates for paper submissions are below:

  • Paper Submission: August 1st (AoE)
  • Author Notification: August 15th (AoE)
  • Camera-Ready Submission: August 29th (AoE)
